messageBody:
I'm with J.B. on this one. The client tells us what business problem they want solved, they tell us the definition of "solved" and then they decide whether our lovingly crafted software meets their definition of "solved" within the timeframes and expenses that they are willing to allow us.

Notice the pattern here? The client ALWAYS decides.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>Sent: Friday, August 22, 2003 12:30 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals
>urgently)
>
>
>Michael Holly wrote:
>
>> Your definiton of Better Software lacks any sort of
>standards to make a
>> quantitative analysis.
>
>On the contrary: it admits the single most important
>quantitative analysis.
>
> How many dollars are my clients willing to pay
> me to continue building their software?
>
>> How fast? How much value? What is business value? Unless
>your definition
>> contains definable
>> quantities then your definition is vague and ambiguous.
>
>Fast enough so that my client is willing to keep paying me.*
>They decide
>how fast that is based -- one hopes -- on their ROI analysis,
>which they
>quantify.
>
>Enough value so that my client is willing to keep paying me.....
>
>>Who determines the
>> business value?
>
>The client. Always.
>
>> Do you go out and get ROI numbers on the projects you do for
>your customers?
>
>Actually yes. I just asked a client to estimate cost savings based on
>software of mine that they used. They quantified it for me.
>
>> Or is business
>> value a feel good thing that you and your customer agree on
>at the end of
>> the project?
>
>The client defines business value continuously throughout the project.
>
>Take care.
>
>-----
>* I might factor in how much future business I can expect from
>referrals, but let us keep the model simple for now.
